case_name: State of Mysore v. the respondent

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1420 of 1966 was filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1420 of 1966. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated October 21, 1965 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 2173 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 21, 1965 of the Mysore High Court in Writ Petition No. 2173 of 1964.

facts.text: Mysore High Court quashed the memorandum dated July 4, 1963 whereby the State Government terminated the service of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is against the Judg- ment and Order of the High Court of Mysore quashing the memorandum dated July 4, 1963 whereby the State G

facts.text: Respondent entered government service as an officiating companyputor in the Government Press on March 11, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent entered government service as an officiating companyputor in the Government Press on March 11, 1958 and company- tinued in that post until September 1, 1958.

facts.text: Respondent continued in that post until September 1, 1958.

anchor.surface_text: tinued in that post until September 1, 1958. He was thereafter appointed from time to time in officiating capacity in different posts

facts.text: Respondent was appointed as a proof examiner on December 3, 1959.

anchor.surface_text: He was thereafter appointed from time to time in officiating capacity in different posts though in the same department until December 3, 1959 when he was appointed as a proof examiner.

facts.text: Respondent continued as proof examiner until February 28, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: He companytinued in that post until February 28, 1961.

facts.text: Appellants claim there was a break in respondent's service on March 1, 1961 as his service was terminated on February 28, 1961 and he was reappointed on March 2, 1961 as a second division clerk industrial.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellants there was break in his service on March 1, 1961 as his service was terminated on February 28, 1961 and he was once again appointed on March 2, 1961 as a second division clerk  industrial.

facts.text: March 1, 1961 was a holiday.

anchor.surface_text: . . He companytinued in that post until July 4, 1963 when the impugned order terminating his service was passed. The first of March 1961 on which it was said there was break in his service was a holiday.

facts.text: Respondent continued in the post of second division clerk industrial until July 4, 1963 when service terminated.

anchor.surface_text: The first of March 1961 on which it was said there was break in his service was a holiday. There is numberdispute that the respondent was throughout work- ing in officiating capacity

facts.text: No dispute that respondent was throughout working in officiating capacity and was a local candidate.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the respondent was throughout work- ing in officiating capacity and was a local candidate like several other such employees appointed by direct recruitment by Government

facts.text: Government Order No. GAD 46 SRR dated September 22, 1961 was passed to regularise appointments of local candidates.

anchor.surface_text: the only question arising in this appeal is one of interpretation of the Government Order No. GAD 46 SRR, dated September 22, 1961.

facts.text: All appointments to Class III Direct Recruitment Posts made up to 31st December 1959 inclusive may be regularised subject to conditions.

anchor.surface_text: The material portion of the said order runs as follows 2. All appointments to Class III Direct Recruitment Posts made by the local appointing authorities, both in the old Mysore area  including Bellary District  and in the other integrating areas up to 31st December 1959  inclusive  may be regularised

facts.text: Services of local candidates shall be regularised with effect from the date of their appointment from which their service is continuous provided they were in service on 1st January 1960 and continue to be in service at the time their services are regularised.

anchor.surface_text: The services of local candidates shall be regularised with effect from the date of their appointment, from which their service is companytinuous provided they were in service on 1st January 1960 and companytinue to be in service at the time their services are regularised.

facts.text: Local service will count for purposes of leave, pension and increments but not for purposes of seniority only the service from the date of regularisation will count for seniority.

anchor.surface_text: The local service will companynt for purposes of leave, pension and increments but number for purposes of seniority only the service from the date of regularisation of their appointments in the particular department will companynt for seniority

facts.text: Breaks in service will not be condoned even if such breaks are only for short periods.

anchor.surface_text: Breaks in service will number be companydoned even if such breaks are only for short periods.

facts.text: Respondent filed Writ Petition against impugned order dated July 4, 1963 claiming entitlement to regularisation under the order and protection of Article 311(2).

anchor.surface_text: In the Writ Petition filed by the respondent against the im- pugned order dated July 4, 1963 terminating his service the respondent raised two points -- 1  that though he was a local candidate appointed from time to time to the aforesaid posts he was entitled to have his service regularised under the said order

facts.text: State Government contended that the order of regularisation did not apply as respondent's service was not continuous.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the State Government on the other hand was that the order of regularisation did number apply to the respondent as his service was number companytinuous as required by the said order

facts.text: High Court held respondent entitled to regularisation with effect from date his service was continuous prior to December 31, 1959 and termination violative of Article 311.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court on an interpretation of the Order dated September 22, 1961 repelled the Governments companytentions and held that the respondent was entitled to have his service regularised with effect from the date his service was companytinuous prior to December 31, 1959

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that continuity of service from January 1, 1960 until September 22, 1961 is required for regularisation.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the express words used in this sub-clause that companytinuity of service from January 1, 1960 until the date of the order is a companydition prescribed for regularisation.

facts.text: Break in respondent's service was only of one day, March 1, 1961, assuming there was such a break.

anchor.surface_text: He also assured us on behalf of the State Government that since the break in the service of the respondent during the material time was only of one day, viz., March 1, 1961, assuming there was such a break

facts.text: Appeal is dismissed due to assurance by Government counsel that respondent's service regularisation will not be affected.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the express words used in this sub-clause that companytinuity of service from January 1, 1960 until the date of the order is a companydition prescribed for regularisation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of sub-clause ii requires continuous service from 1 January 1960 to order date for eligibility to regularisation

holdings.text: This construction finds support from sub-clause iii which provides that local service prior to regularisation would be counted for the purposes of leave, pension and increments though not for seniority

anchor.surface_text: This construction finds support from sub-clause iii which provides that local service prior to regularisation would be companynted for the purposes of leave, pension and increments though number for seniority as seniority was to be fixed from the length of service calculated from the date of regularisation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-clause iii implies continuity as prior service counts for benefits like increments and pension only if continuous

holdings.text: Continuity of service is thus a condition for both sub-clauses 2 and 3

anchor.surface_text: Continuity of service is thus a condition for both sub- clauses 2 and 3.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-clause iv prohibiting condonation of breaks applies to ensure continuity required under ii and iii

holdings.text: The High Court was therefore in error when it said that sub-clause iv did not relate to considerations under sub-clause ii or that it had reference only to a break in service before December 31, 1959

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore in error when it said that sub-clause iv did number relate to companysiderations under sub-clause ii or that it had reference only to a break

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-clause iv generally prohibits condoning breaks, supporting continuity requirement across clauses

holdings.text: The High Court was also in error when it construed sub-clause ii to mean that the only thing it required was, that the candidate had to be appointed initially prior to December 31, 1959 and that he had to be in service on the two dates, viz., January 1, 1960 and September 22, 1961 and that the service during the interval need not be continuous

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was also in error when it companystrued sub-clause ii to mean that the only thing it required was, that the candidate had to be appointed initially prior to December 31, 1959 and that he had to be in service on the two dates, viz., January 1, 1960 and September 22, 1961 and that the service during the interval need number be companytinuous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court ignored express continuity language in sub-clause ii by limiting to termini only

holdings.text: Therefore the proper interpretation would be that in order that the regularisation order may apply to a particular case the local candidate must be initially appointed prior to December 31, 1959, he must be in service on January 1, 1960 and continue to be in service without any break till the date of the said order

anchor.surface_text: Therefore the proper interpretation would be that in order that the regularisation order may apply to a particular case the local, candidate must be initially appointed prior to December 31, 1959, he must be in service on January 1, 1960 and companytinue to be in service without any break till the date of the said order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Combines sub i, ii requirements with continuity to avoid injustice in seniority

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overall scheme requires continuity to harmonise benefits, breaks, and seniority provisions

Fact of respondent's entry into service as an officiating (temporary) companyputor satisfies the rule's definition of a local candidate as a temporary servant not appointed regularly via recruitment rules.
The fact of temporary officiating entry supports the issue's premise of being a local candidate appointed from time to time, underlying the regularization claim.

edges.explanation: Issue explicitly addresses the local candidate concept by stating he was a local candidate appointed from time to time.
The issue's reference to being a 'local candidate' requires the application and definition provided by Rule 8(27A) to assess the claim of entitlement to service regularization.

The issue claims entitlement to service regularization for a local candidate under the said order, which pertains to Rule 1A Mysore Government Servants Seniority Rules on local candidates and regularization
